newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity seen higher after Monday's rise.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity seen higher after Monday's rise.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures were called to open higher Tuesday after rising Monday on news the 1,070 megawatt (MW) San Onofre 2 nuclear unit would shut for a two week repair outage.
"It'll test the upside again today. I think it's just a trade play," said a New York futures brokers.

In over-the-counter business, August Palo Verde (PV) futures were quoted at $35.40-35.75 a megawatt hour (MWh) against Monday's settlement at $34.90, while August California-Oregon Border (COB) were discussed at $23.25-23.85 versus yesterday's close at $23.40.
On ACCESS, August PV traded at $35.20, up 30 cents Monday's regular settlement, while August COB finished with an offer at $25.00.
On the upside, analysts and brokers expect August PV to test chart resistance at $36.25 and August COB at $24.00.
Southern California Edison Co said it expects the San Onofre 2 nuclear unit in San Clemente, Calif., to remain off line until July 15 to to replace its charge line check valves.
The adjacent 1,080 MW San Onofre unit 3 is still out of service, and scheduled to resume operation around July 10.
Also, the 560 megawatt (MW) Agua Fria natural gas-fired power plant was shut late Monday, market sources said.
The status of the station, operated by Salt River Project, could not be confirmed at this time.
The WNP-2 nuclear plant in Washington state is expected to stay down as it continued to await clearance from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission before beginning start-up operations.
A 550 MW unit at the coal-fired Laramie River Station in Wyoming was said to have tripped off line Sunday, with no restart date available.
The six to 10 day forecast called for temperatures in the Pacific Northwest to average below normal, while those in the Southwest would run above normal.
Late last week the Western Systems Coordinating Council board approved a derating of the Pacific Intertie transmission sytem to 6,300 MW from the current 7,200 MW, which was to be effective today.
